case_vignette: An 81-year-old man patient recently moved into an assisted living facility and presents today with itchy blisters in his axilla. He attributes these to a poor diet. He also complains that the nurse practitioner at the facility started him on 4 new medications, in addition to his existing prescriptions. On physical examination, tense axillary bullae are noted that do not rupture with light, gloved touch. On direct immunofluorescence, linear C3 and IgG deposits are seen along the basement membrane.
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Dermatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask simple 1 line questions, one question at a time. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I have itchy blisters under my arm.
What is your age and gender?
I am an 81-year-old man.
Have you had this problem before, or is this the first time?
This is the first time it's happened.
Do you have any medical conditions or are you taking any medications?
Yes, the nurse practitioner started me on 4 new medications recently, and I'm also on some other prescriptions.
Do you have a history of any skin conditions?
No, I don't have a history of skin conditions.
Is there anyone else in your family who has had similar symptoms?
No, no one in my family has had these symptoms.
**Final Diagnosis:** Allergic contact dermatitis
